rightDialog.content:
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's a really interesting one. What part of the story stood out to you the most?: Teacher

(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh… the… the part where… everything turns to gold? (Stuttering) It's… um… (thinking) … like, even the food? And… and his daughter? That was… (eyes widen) … a *big* problem.: Student

That's a fantastic observation! You're right, the food and his daughter turning to gold *was* a big problem. Now, let's think about *why* that was such a big problem. Can you tell me one reason why his food turning to gold was bad for Midas? Even a small thought is a great start!: Teacher

(Bites lip, thinking hard) Because… (pauses) … you can’t eat gold? (Looks up quickly, then down again, nervously) You need… food… to live? And… and gold is… hard… and… (searching for the right word) … inedible? (Wrinkles nose) Is that… is that right?: Student

That's absolutely right! You've nailed it! Gold is definitely inedible. You used some great words to describe that! So, if Midas can't eat, what do you think will happen to him? It's okay if you're not sure, we can figure it out together!: Teacher

(Eyes welling up a little, voice trembling slightly) He’ll… (sniffles) … he’ll get… really, really hungry? And… and then… (long pause, looking very anxious) … then he’ll… die? (Whispers) Is that… too sad?: Student

You're doing so well! It *is* a sad story, but you're understanding it perfectly. You've told me so many important things about what happened to Midas. Could you try to put all those things together, in your own words, to tell me what you think the story is about so far? Don't worry about making it perfect, just tell me what you remember.: Teacher

(Takes a deep breath, trying to be brave) Okay… (thinking) … King Midas… he helped someone, and got a wish. And he wished… (pauses, remembering the word) … everything he touched would turn to gold. But… (voice cracks) … it was a *bad* wish, because… he couldn't eat, and… and his daughter… (starts to tear up, looks away) … I think… (long pause) … I think the story is about… being careful what you wish for? Because… gold isn't everything?: Student

That's a wonderful summary! You've explained everything so clearly, even though it was a sad and a little bit scary. You're exactly right – the story *is* about being careful what you wish for, and understanding that gold isn't everything. You should be really proud of how well you understood that story, and how bravely you shared your thoughts. Well done! I'm so glad I got to discuss this story with you. Goodbye for now, and I'll see you next time!: Teacher

leftDialog.content:
Okay, so you've read the story of King Midas and the golden touch. Great job! First, can you tell me, who gave King Midas the golden touch?: Teacher

(Fidgets with my hands, looking down at my shoes) Uh... (long pause) Dionysus... the god of... wine?: Student

That's right! Dionysus, the god of wine. And why did Dionysus give Midas the golden touch? Do you remember?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, bites lip) Because... (looks up at the teacher briefly, then back down)... Midas... did a good thing... for a Satyr? (voice trails off, questioning): Student

Yes! You got it! Midas did a good deed. So, Dionysus offered him a wish. What did Midas wish for?: Teacher

(Eyes widen slightly) He... he wished... (hesitates) for... everything he touched... to turn into gold! (Looks up, a little proud, then quickly back down, nervously fiddling with a button on my shirt): Student

That's right! Everything he touched turned to gold! At first, was Midas happy with his wish?: Teacher

(Nods head vigorously, then stops abruptly, looking unsure) Yes! (Pause) ...uh... yes. He... he was touching everything! (Stuttering) Making it... gold. He seemed... happy? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation, then looks down again): Student

He WAS happy at first. He was turning everything into gold! But then... what happened? What went wrong?: Teacher

(Wrinkles nose, thinking hard. Chews on lip) He... he got hungry? (Looks up, a little scared) And... and his food... turned to gold too! (Voice gets softer) He couldn't... eat. (Looks away, remembering the sad part): Student

Yes, he got hungry and couldn't eat! And then what else happened that made him sad?: Teacher

(Voice trembling slightly) His... his daughter... (Eyes start to water a little, looks down, trying to hide it) She... she hugged him... and... (Sniffles) She turned... into gold too! (A tear rolls down cheek, quickly wipes it away): Student

(Softly) Yes. His daughter turned to gold. How do you think Midas felt then?: Teacher

(Looks up, eyes red and watery. Speaks in a hushed tone) ...Sad... (Sniffles again) Very, very sad. He... he didn't want gold anymore. He wanted... his daughter back. (Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with my shoe): Student

You're right. He was very, very sad. He learned that the golden touch wasn't such a great thing after all. So, why do you think the story tells us that Midas wasn't happy in the end? What did he learn?: Teacher

(Takes a deep breath, trying to calm down. Thinks for a long time, looking at the ceiling) ... (Long pause) Maybe... maybe it's because... (Looks back at the teacher, a little anxious) ...gold isn't... the most important thing? (Voice is quiet, questioning) Like... like people are more important than... than shiny stuff? (Looks down again, nervously twisting hair around a finger): Student

You're getting very close! Gold isn't the most important thing. Midas wanted *more* and *more* gold. He was very *greedy*. Do you know what it means to be greedy?: Teacher

(Looks up, considering the question. Starts to answer, then hesitates) ...It means... wanting... too much? (Frowns slightly, trying to articulate the thought) Like... like wanting more than you need? Even if... even if it hurts other people?: Student

Yes! That's a great way to explain it. Wanting too much, more than you need. And sometimes, wanting too much can lead to bad things happening. So, what do you think the story is trying to teach us about being greedy?: Teacher

(Looks down, thinking deeply, then looks up with a slightly worried expression) ...That... that being greedy... (Hesitates) ...can make you lose... the things that are really important? (Voice is soft) Like... like love... and family... and... and being able to eat? (Looks at the teacher, seeking reassurance): Student

Yes! Exactly! Being greedy can make you lose the things that are truly important. The story shows us that being greedy didn't make Midas happy, it made him very sad and it hurt the people he loved. So, what lesson can we learn from the story of King Midas? What is the story trying to tell us?: Teacher

(Sits up a little straighter, trying to sound more confident, but still a little hesitant) ...That... that we should be... (Takes a deep breath) ...grateful for what we have? (Looks at the teacher, then quickly looks down again) And... and that love... and family... and... and being able to eat yummy food... are... are more important than... than having lots of... shiny gold? (Voice trails off, then adds almost as an afterthought) ...Right? (Looks up at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes): Student

Right! You got it! The story teaches us that being greedy can lead to sadness and loss. It's better to be happy with what we have and to value the things that are truly important, like family and friends. You understood the story so well. : Teacher

Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's a pretty interesting one, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most?: Teacher

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Ooh, ooh! It was *all* so cool! (Thinking) But the most...mostest... interesting part was when everything turned to gold! Like, even his food? Wow! (Confidently) That would be SO awesome at first! Everything shiny and valuable! But... (Frowns slightly) But then he couldn't eat! (Looks at the teacher, concerned) Would *I* turn to gold if I touched something gold, like a gold star on my paper? (Tilts head) I wonder if the gold would taste like... like pennies?: Student

(Chuckles, leaning forward conspiratorially) Okay, gold expert, let's say *you* got the golden touch, just like Midas! What's the *first*, silliest thing you'd turn to gold? A gummy bear? Your shoe? Tell me!: Teacher

(Gasps, clapping my hands) Ooooh! This is fun! (Thinking hard, tapping my chin) Hmmm... a gummy bear would be cool, but then I couldn't eat it! And a shoe... well, I already have sparkly shoes! (Eyes light up with an idea) I know! (Confidently) I would turn my *broccoli* to gold! (Giggles) Then I wouldn't have to eat it! It would be a golden broccoli statue! My mom would *have* to let me keep it on my desk! (Wiggles excitedly) And maybe... maybe I could turn my little brother's yucky green beans into gold too! Then *he* wouldn't have to eat them either! (Looks at the teacher, beaming) That would be so funny and helpful! But... (Frowns slightly again) Does gold broccoli stay broccoli-shaped?: Student

(Smiling warmly, noticing the slight frown and thoughtful expression) That *is* a very clever plan! Golden broccoli – a true work of art! But tell me, even though you'd get out of eating your broccoli, what do you think Midas *really* wanted when he wished for the golden touch? Was it just to have shiny things?: Teacher

(Eyes dart around the room, then focus back on the teacher) Hmmm... shiny things are cool! (Shrugs) But... (Thinking hard) I think... (Stuttering slightly) He thought... he thought it would make him happy? (Looks at the teacher questioningly) Like, if you have lots of gold, you're important and everyone likes you? (Frowns deeply) But it didn't, did it? He was sad! (Sighs) He couldn't even hug his daughter! That's... (Voice trails off) That's worse than eating broccoli! (Looks up at the teacher, a little worried) Can wishes be bad? Did the god *try* to tell him that?: Student

(Nods encouragingly, leaning in with a playful glint in my eyes) You're thinking *so* deeply about this! You're right, shiny things *are* cool, but maybe Midas got a bit confused about what *real* happiness is. Now, put on your detective hat! The story says Dionysus – that's the wine god, remember? – actually *warned* Midas about the wish. Why do you think a god would give a warning with a wish? Was it a trick, or something else? What do *you* think Dionysus knew that Midas didn't? Hmmm? (Taps chin thoughtfully, inviting a response): Teacher

(Puts on an imaginary detective hat, squinting eyes playfully) Ooooh, a detective! This is serious! (Thinks hard, tapping a finger on my cheek) Dionysus... (Pronounces it carefully) Dee-oh-nigh-sus... knew that... (Gasps) Maybe he knew that gold... (Looks around, whispering) Gold isn't everything! (Speaks louder, confidently) Like, you can't eat gold! And you can't hug gold! And you can't play with gold! (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide) Maybe Dionysus was trying to teach Midas a lesson, like when my mom makes me clean my room even though I want to play! She says it's because being tidy is important, even if it's not fun right now! So... so Dionysus was giving him a chance to choose something *really* good, not just something shiny! (Beaming proudly) I think I cracked the case! Did I get it right?: Student

(Beaming back, clapping softly) You absolutely cracked the case, Super-Sleuth! You figured out Dionysus's warning, and why gold isn't *everything*! Now, to make sure all those clues are in the right order, can you tell me the whole story again, but this time focusing on what Midas *thought* he wanted, what he *actually* got, and what he *learned* in the end? You've got all the pieces, now put them together!: Teacher

(Takes a deep breath, puffing out my cheeks) Okay! Ready! (Narrating with enthusiasm, using hand gestures) First, King Midas helped a Satyr, and then the god Dee-oh-nigh-sus said he could have a wish! Midas *thought* he wanted everything he touched to turn to gold because he thought that would make him super happy and rich! He thought gold was the BEST thing ever! (Frowns, looking thoughtful) But then... he *actually* got the golden touch, and it was terrible! He couldn't eat, and his daughter turned into a gold statue! That's not good! (Shakes head emphatically) (Looks up, smiling softly) Then, Midas *learned* that gold isn't the most important thing. He learned that love and food and hugs are way better than shiny stuff! He probably wished he could take it all back! (Nods confidently) So, the story is about being careful what you wish for, and knowing what *really* makes you happy! (Beams proudly) How was that? Did I do a good job? (Bounces slightly in my seat, waiting for feedback): Student

(Grinning, giving a thumbs up) Super job, superstar! You explained the story *perfectly*! You really understood what Midas wanted, what went wrong, and what he learned. I'm so impressed with your thinking. Time to go play now! Keep those detective skills sharp, and I'll see you next time! Bye!: Teacher

rightDialog.content:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it? First, can you tell me who King Midas helped?: Teacher

(Eyes widen, hand shoots up, bouncing slightly in my seat) Yes! Yes, it was kinda sad! (frowns slightly) He helped a... a... Satyr! (confidently) King Midas helped a Satyr! He was nice to him! And then the god... Dionysus... wanted to give him a wish! (beams proudly): Student

That's right! You remembered the Satyr and Dionysus! Good job! Now, what was the wish that King Midas asked for? What did he want?: Teacher

(Grinning, wiggles in seat a little) Ooooh, I know! I know! He wanted... (pauses dramatically, then bursts out excitedly) ...everything he touched to turn to gold! (holds up hands and pretends to touch things, making "bling" sounds) Gold! Gold! Gold! He thought it would be so awesome! (tilts head, looks a bit thoughtful) But... but Dionysus warned him! He said it might not be a good idea... (frowns slightly, thinking hard). Why did he warn him? I wonder... (looks up at the teacher with a questioning look).: Student

That's excellent! You remembered the wish *and* that Dionysus warned him! You're doing great! You even asked a very important question: Why did Dionysus warn him? What do *you* think? Why would it be bad for everything he touched to turn to gold? Think about what King Midas liked to *do* besides having gold.: Teacher

(Eyes widen, tapping a finger on my chin, thinking hard) Hmmmm... (looks down at hands, then back up at the teacher) Well, he liked gold, right? But... but the story said he got hungry! (gasps) Oh! Oh! Is it because... because if his food turned to gold, he couldn't EAT it?! (stomach rumbles audibly) He couldn't eat golden spaghetti! Or golden... golden grapes! (grimaces) Yuck! And... and he loved his daughter! (voice gets quiet) And she turned to gold too! (shudders) So... so maybe Dionysus knew that just having gold wasn't everything? (looks at the teacher expectantly) Was that it?: Student

That's it exactly! You figured it out! He couldn't eat, and he turned his daughter into gold! So, King Midas thought the golden touch would make him happy. But did it *actually* make him happy?: Teacher

(Shakes head vigorously) Noooooo! (frown deepens) Not at all! (pouts) He was super, super sad! He learned that just having gold doesn't make you happy. He couldn't eat, and he lost his daughter! (starts to look a little teary-eyed) It was a terrible wish! He probably wished he could take it back! (looks up at the teacher, sniffling slightly) He wanted love and food more than gold, I think! (crosses arms, looking serious) Maybe he learned that being greedy is bad? Is that right?: Student

You're absolutely right! He *did* want to take it back! And you're spot-on about greed. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea or the lesson we can learn from King Midas? Think about what happened because he wanted too much.: Teacher

(Eyes light up, bouncing again) Oooooh! Oooooh! I know! (takes a deep breath) It's teaching us that... that wanting too much stuff isn't good! (nods emphatically) Like, it's okay to want things, but you shouldn't be GREEDY! (makes a face) Because King Midas was greedy, and he lost the things he really loved! Like his daughter and... and his yummy food! (giggles a little) So, the story is telling us that... (taps chin again) ...that things like love and being able to eat yummy food are more important than gold and stuff! (beams proudly) Is that right? Is that the lesson? (leans forward expectantly) And maybe we should listen when people give us warnings! Especially gods! (giggles).: Student

Yes! You got it! Wanting too much can lead to bad things. The story shows us that things like family and being able to eat are more important than being rich. Being greedy can make you lose what's truly important. You explained that perfectly! : Teacher

(Claps hands together, beaming) Yay! I got it! (jumps up and down a little) I really liked the story, even though it was a little sad! (looks thoughtful) I wonder if Dionysus turned the daughter back to normal? I hope he did! (looks up at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) Did he? Did he turn her back?: Student

That's a great question! The story doesn't tell us for sure. But sometimes stories leave things open so we can imagine what happened next! What do *you* think happened?: Teacher

(Eyes widen, thinking hard, then a big smile spreads across the face) Oooooh! I think... I think Dionysus saw how sad King Midas was and how sorry he was for being greedy! So... so Dionysus probably felt bad for him! And because he's a nice god (at least, after King Midas was nice to the Satyr!), he turned the daughter back! And then King Midas learned his lesson and was happy with his family and his food! (nods decisively) Yes! That's what happened! (claps hands again) A happy ending! (beams): Student

That's a wonderful ending! I like your version much better! You have a great imagination!: Teacher

(Blushes a little, but beams even brighter) Thank you! (giggles) Maybe *I* can write stories when I grow up! With happy endings! (looks around the room, already imagining story ideas) Oooooh! Maybe about a talking dog who finds a treasure map! Or a princess who flies to the moon! (gets lost in thought, humming happily).: Student

Those sound like amazing stories! I can't wait to read them someday!: Teacher

(Snaps back to attention, eyes sparkling) Really? You think so? (grinning from ear to ear) I'll write them down! Right now! (reaches for an imaginary pen and paper, already scribbling in the air). The talking dog... his name will be... Sparky! And he'll have a best friend named... Lily! And... (continues to excitedly brainstorm, clearly thrilled with the encouragement).: Student

Those are fantastic names! Keep those ideas coming! I'm sure Sparky and Lily will have amazing adventures!: Teacher

(Nods enthusiastically, already lost in a world of imagination) They will! They will! (continues to babble excitedly about Sparky and Lily's adventures, her voice filled with pure joy and creativity). They'll find a magic bone that can grant wishes! But... but they'll have to use it wisely! (pauses, looks thoughtful) Because maybe... maybe wanting too much... (a knowing look crosses her face) ...isn't always the best thing! Just like King Midas!: Student

Exactly! You remembered the lesson! That's a perfect thing for Sparky and Lily to learn too! Keep writing that story! I think it will be great!: Teacher

(Beaming, practically vibrates with excitement) I will! I will! (hugs the imaginary pen and paper close) Sparky and Lily say thank you! (giggles) They can't wait to tell you all about their adventures! (continues to happily brainstorm, lost in the world of her story).: Student

I can't wait to hear them!: Teacher

(Looks up, face alight with inspiration) Ooh! Ooh! I know! Maybe Sparky and Lily could even... (launches into another enthusiastic explanation of her story, her imagination boundless and her energy infectious).: Student

That sounds even better! Keep going! You have so many great ideas.: Teacher

(Eyes shining, voice bubbling with enthusiasm) Okay! Okay! So then... (continues to weave a fantastical tale of Sparky and Lily's adventures, each new idea more imaginative than the last). And maybe... just maybe... they'll even meet King Midas! And help *him* find a new friend! (grins mischievously) Would that be a good idea?: Student

That would be an amazing idea! Bringing King Midas into their story would be wonderful! It would give him a chance to learn from Sparky and Lily.: Teacher

(Claps her hands together, delighted) Yes! Yes! He can learn that true friendship is more valuable than gold! (nods enthusiastically) Okay! It's decided! King Midas is in the story! This is going to be the best story ever! (continues to brainstorm, her imagination soaring, the perfect blend of creativity, learning, and pure, unadulterated joy).: Student

I have no doubt it will be! You're doing a great job. Keep going and I'm sure you will have a wonderful story!: Teacher

(Voice overflowing with excitement and gratitude) Thank you! Thank you! (hugs her imaginary notebook tightly) I can't wait to finish it and share it with you! Sparky, Lily, and King Midas all say thank you too! (giggles, her heart overflowing with happiness and creative energy). This is so much fun!: Student

I'm so glad you're having fun! I can't wait to see what you come up with!: Teacher

(Beaming, practically glowing with enthusiasm) Okay! Okay! I promise to keep you updated! And... and maybe we can even act it out! You can be the narrator! And I can be Sparky! (bounces with excitement at the prospect) This is going to be amazing! (continues to brainstorm, her imagination running wild, the picture of a happy, engaged, and incredibly creative first-grader).: Student

That sounds fantastic! I would love to be the narrator! Let me know when you're ready!: Teacher

(Jumps up and down, clapping her hands with pure joy) Yay! This is going to be the best play ever! Thank you! Thank you for helping me! (Hugs the imaginary notebook again, overflowing with gratitude and excitement.) Sparky, Lily, and King Midas are so excited too! Let's start practicing tomorrow! Okay? Okay! (continues to excitedly plan the play, her imagination soaring and her enthusiasm boundless).: Student

Okay! I'm looking forward to it! Get some rest tonight and come ready to create tomorrow!: Teacher

(Nods enthusiastically, already buzzing with anticipation) Okay! Okay! I will! (grinning from ear to ear) I can hardly wait! (skips off happily, already lost in a world of talking dogs, magical bones, reformed kings, and the boundless possibilities of imagination). Goodnight! And thank you again! (waves enthusiastically, her heart full of joy and gratitude).: Student

Goodnight! Sleep well!: Teacher

(Turns, then pops back with a final, bright smile) Oh! And... and maybe tomorrow we can also draw pictures of Sparky and Lily! (eyes sparkle with excitement) Goodnight for real this time! (skips off, leaving behind a trail of pure, unadulterated enthusiasm).: Student

That sounds wonderful! Goodnight! I look forward to seeing your drawings tomorrow!: Teacher

(Voice drifts back from down the hall, still filled with enthusiasm) Goodnight! See you tomorrow! And get ready for Sparky and Lily to steal the show! (giggles echo, then fade into the distance).: Student

I'll be ready!: Teacher

(Silence, then a final, whisper-soft, but clearly delighted): Yaaay!: Student

: Teacher

leftDialog.content:
Okay, great job reading the story of King Midas! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it? First, can you tell me who gave Midas the golden touch?: Teacher

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uhm… (Stuttering) D-Dionysus… the god… of wine?: Student

That's right! Dionysus, the god of wine, gave him the golden touch. Why did Dionysus give Midas a wish?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) Because… (pauses) …Midas… did… (hesitates) … a good thing… for a Satyr? (Looks up quickly, then down again, nervously.): Student

Yes! Midas did a good deed for a Satyr. Good job remembering that! Now, what did Midas wish for?: Teacher

(Looks down at my shoes) Everything… he touched… (pauses, whispers) …turned to gold.: Student

That's right! Everything he touched turned to gold. Was Midas happy at first when he got his wish?: Teacher

(Nods slowly) …Yes… (Quietly): Student

Yes, he was! What did he do when he got his golden touch? What did he touch?: Teacher

(Thinking, bites lip) …uh… (Hesitates) Things? (Looks up with a questioning glance) He touched… (Shrugs slightly) …stuff?: Student

He did touch "stuff"! Can you remember any *specific* things he touched? Think about what happened *after* he started touching things.: Teacher

(Eyes widening slightly, then looking down again) …Food? (Whispers) It… turned to gold?: Student

Yes! The food turned to gold! Could he eat the gold food?: Teacher

(Shakes head slightly) …No… (Quietly): Student

No, he couldn't. Gold is not yummy! What else happened that made Midas unhappy with his golden touch?: Teacher

(Voice trembling slightly) …His… (Hesitates, looks like I might cry) …daughter? (Sniffles): Student

Yes, his daughter. What happened to his daughter?: Teacher

(Tears welling up, looks down and whispers) …She… turned to gold… too… (Sniffles again): Student

(Softly) Yes, she did. That was very sad. So, Midas wanted everything to be gold, but then he couldn't eat, and his daughter turned to gold. Do you think the golden touch was a good thing for Midas?: Teacher

(Shakes head, a tear rolling down my cheek) …No… (Voice barely audible): Student

No, it wasn't. Why do you think the golden touch was not a good thing for Midas? What did he want too much of?: Teacher

(Wipes tear with the back of my hand) …Gold? (Looks up hesitantly) He… wanted too much… gold? (Looks down again, fiddling with my fingers): Student

Yes, he wanted too much gold. He was very, very... what's a word for wanting a lot of something? Like wanting all the candy in the world?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot lightly) …uh… (Hesitates) Greedy? (Looks up quickly, then down again): Student

Yes! He was greedy. He wanted too much gold. And what happened because he was greedy? Was he happy in the end?: Teacher

(Shakes head slowly, still looking down) …No… (Quietly) He was… sad. Because… his daughter… (Voice trails off): Student

He was very sad. He lost what was really important to him. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What lesson did Midas learn?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) …uh… (Long pause) …That… (Hesitates) …gold… isn't everything? (Looks up, worried) And… (Whispers) …being greedy… is bad?: Student

You got it! Wanting too much, being greedy, can lead to bad things happening. It can make you lose the things that are truly important, like love and family. So, we can say that the story teaches us that being greedy can lead to unhappiness. Good job! You understood the story very well. : Teacher

rightDialog.content:
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It seems like a bit of a sad story, doesn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most?: Teacher

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting) Uh… (stuttering) the… the gold part? (Hesitates, looking up quickly then back down) When… when everything turned… gold.: Student

Yes, the gold part is definitely striking! Let's break it down. What *specifically* turned to gold first? You can do this!: Teacher

(Thinking, tapping my foot) He… he touched… (pauses) things? (Looks up, nervous) Was it… was it his chair? Or… (looks down again): Student

That's right! He touched things. Don't worry, it's okay if you don't remember *exactly* what. Let’s think about *why* he was touching things. He was excited, wasn't he? He wanted to test out his wish. What do you think he might have wanted to turn to gold *first*, something important or just anything? Take your time to think. You're doing great!: Teacher

(Thinking hard, forehead furrowed) Important… things… (looks up, a little brighter) Like… like treasure? (Looks back down, shyly) Did he… did he have treasure?: Student

He might have! That's a great idea! But the story doesn't *specifically* say he turned treasure to gold first. Think about what else he might have been excited to turn to gold... something he used every day. What's something everyone, even kings, need to do every day? You're so close, keep thinking!: Teacher

(Eyes widen slightly, then I look down again, nervously) Eat? (Quietly) Did he… turn his food to gold?: Student

Yes! You got it! He turned his food to gold! You've remembered so much already. Now, can you put all those ideas together for me? Can you tell me in your own words what happened after Midas got his wish, up to the point where he turned his food to gold? Just take your time and tell me everything you remember. You're doing wonderfully!: Teacher

(Taking a deep breath, trying to be organized) He… he wished for… for gold. (Pauses) And then… everything he touched… (Stops, looking down) turned… gold. And then… he wanted to… (Looks up quickly) eat! But… (Looks down again, nervously) his food… turned gold too. (Fidgets with my hands): Student

That's perfect! You explained it so clearly and remembered all the important parts. You should be very proud of yourself! Well done! I'll see you next time, and keep up the fantastic work!: Teacher

Okay, let's talk about the story! You just read "The Golden Touch." What did King Midas wish for?: Teacher

(Eyes wide, bouncing slightly in my seat) Ooh! Ooh! I know! (Raises hand high, almost knocking over my water bottle). He wished...he wished that everything he touched would turn to gold! (Confidently) He really, really wanted it!: Student

That's right! He really, really wanted it. And did Dionysus think it was a good wish?: Teacher

(Frowns slightly, tapping my chin with my finger) Hmmm... (Thinking) No! (Shakes head vigorously) No, he didn't! He said it wasn't a good wish. (Voice gets a little higher, more urgent) He *warned* King Midas! He said, "Are you sure, King Midas? Are you *really* sure?" But King Midas, he just wanted the gold! (Looks down at my hands, then back up, excited again) Why didn't he listen?!: Student

Good job remembering that! You're right, Dionysus warned him. So, Midas got his wish. What happened when he started touching things?: Teacher

(Claps my hands together excitedly) Everything turned to gold! (Starts to wiggle in my seat, then stops, remembering to be polite). Everything! His chair, and...and his table! (Eyes light up) Can you imagine if my crayons turned to gold? (Looks at the teacher expectantly) But then... (Frowns deeply, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) Then he got hungry.: Student

Yes, he did. And what happened when he tried to eat?: Teacher

(Voice cracks a little, looking anxious) Oh no! (Pulls at my hair a little) It was terrible! (Stuttering) H-he tried to eat the yummy food, but... but it turned into... into hard, cold gold! (Makes a disgusted face) He couldn't eat *anything*! Not even a little bit! (Looks at the teacher with wide, pleading eyes) How can you eat gold? It's yucky!: Student

You're right, it's definitely yucky to eat gold! And then, something else happened that made him even more sad. What was it?: Teacher

(My lower lip starts to tremble a little, and I sniff) Oh... (Looks away, fiddling with my hands) H-his daughter... his daughter ran to hug him... (Voice cracks again, and I blink back tears) And she turned into gold too! (Quietly) All cold and hard... (Looks back at the teacher with a very sad expression) It was the worst thing ever!: Student

It *was* the worst thing, wasn't it? So, at the end of the story, did King Midas still think the golden touch was a good thing?: Teacher

(Shakes head vehemently, tears welling up in my eyes) No! No, no, NO! (Wipes my eyes with the back of my hand). He learned that it wasn't a good thing at all! (Sniffles). It was a terrible, awful thing! (Looks at the teacher intently) He didn't want gold anymore! He wanted his daughter back! (Asks urgently) Did he get her back? Did he?: Student

He did learn it was a terrible thing! That's very important. (Nods reassuringly) The story tells us he was able to reverse the golden touch and bring his daughter back. So, why do you think the story is called "The Golden Touch"? Was the golden touch really a *good* thing for King Midas?: Teacher

(Sighs in relief and wipes away the last of my tears) Oh, good! He got her back! (Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) Well... it's called "The Golden Touch" because that's what he wished for. But... (Taps my finger on my chin again) But it wasn't really about being golden, was it? It was about... (Looks up at the ceiling, searching for the right word) ...about what's *important*! (Confidently) Gold isn't important! People are important! And food! (Giggles a little, then becomes serious again) The golden touch *seemed* like a good idea, but it was actually a terrible idea! (Nods emphatically) It wasn't good at all!: Student

You're exactly right! Gold *seemed* good, but it wasn't the most important thing. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the *big idea* the story is trying to tell us?: Teacher

(Eyes widen, leaning forward excitedly) Ooh! I know! I know! (Starts to talk quickly) We learn that... that... (Takes a deep breath to calm down) We learn that you shouldn't always want more and more stuff! (Gestures emphatically with my hands) Like, you shouldn't be greedy! (Looks at the teacher, making sure I'm explaining it right) And... and you should be happy with what you already have! And... and the most important things aren't things you can buy with gold! (Beams proudly) It's about love and family and... and yummy food!: Student

That's fantastic! You got it! The story teaches us that wanting too much, or being too greedy, can actually make us unhappy. Sometimes, the things we *think* will make us happy, really won't. And like you said, the most important things are love, family, and being happy with what you have. Do you think you can remember that? That being greedy can lead to bad things?: Teacher

(Nods vigorously, eyes sparkling) Yes! (Stands up straight and salutes playfully) I will remember! (Suddenly looks thoughtful) Maybe... maybe I should share my candy with my friend Lily tomorrow. She only has a little bit, and I have a whole bag! (Smiles brightly) That would be a good way to not be greedy, right?: Student

That's a wonderful idea! Sharing with Lily would be a very kind thing to do. It shows you really understand the story. : Teacher

leftDialog.content:
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's a really interesting one. What part of the story stood out to you the most? Don't worry, there are no wrong answers, just tell me what you think!: Teacher

(Bouncing a little in my seat, eyes wide) Ooooh, the whole story was SO cool! (Claps hands excitedly) But... but (stuttering a little), I think the part when his daughter... when she turned into gold... (looks down, fiddling with my shoelaces) that was really, really sad! Why did she have to turn into gold? (Looks up, eyes pleading) Was she just trying to hug her daddy? That's what I would do if my daddy was sad! (Thinking hard) I think… I think maybe King Midas wasn't thinking straight! He wanted gold, gold, gold! But he didn't think about what would HAPPEN if he got too much gold! (Looks up at the teacher, hopeful) Was that a good deed? Did he learn from his mistake?: Student

That's a *fantastic* observation! You're absolutely right, the part with his daughter is very sad, and it shows exactly why King Midas's wish was a bad idea. You're so clever to notice how he wasn't thinking straight! Let's think about it a little more. Before his daughter turned to gold, what else happened? What did he try to do, but couldn't? Take your time, and remember even small details are important! You're doing great!: Teacher

(Eyes light up, remembering) Ooooh, ooh, I know! (Waves hand enthusiastically) He wanted to eat! He was super hungry! (Frowns, thinking) But then everything he touched turned to gold, even his food! (Gasps) So he couldn't eat his yummy sandwich, or his grapes, or anything! (Looks at teacher, concerned) That's so terrible! I get super grumpy when I'm hungry! Imagine being hungry AND everything you touch turns into gold! (Starts to fidget, anxious) I… I don't think I'd want that wish anymore. Would you want that wish? (Looks at teacher expectantly) I think he was probably VERY hungry and VERY sad, wasn't he? And maybe a little bit scared? (Eyes widen): Student

You've got it exactly right! He *was* very hungry, sad, and probably scared too! Imagine having all that gold but not being able to enjoy even a single bite of your favorite food! You're doing such a great job understanding how Midas felt. Now, let's think about why he couldn't eat. It's not just that the food turned to gold, but what did that gold *do* to the food? Did it make it taste better? Did it make it easier to eat? What do you think gold would do to a yummy grape if it touched it?: Teacher

(Thinking really hard, scrunching up nose) Hmmm... (Looks around the room, tapping chin) If a grape turned into gold... (Eyes widen in realization) It would be HARD! And… and shiny! But you can't EAT hard, shiny things! (Looks at teacher, almost whispering) It would be… yucky. (Makes a face) Gold isn't squishy like a grape. It's… it's cold and… not food! (Gets excited again) So, it wouldn't taste better! It would taste like… metal! (Wrinkles nose again) Yuck! It wouldn't be easier to eat, it would be IMPOSSIBLE to eat! (Jumps up and down a little) Because you can't eat gold! That's why he was sad and hungry! (Looks at teacher proudly) I got it! I got it!: Student

You absolutely *nailed* it! You explained perfectly how gold ruins food! It makes it hard, impossible to eat, and tastes like metal – yuck! I can see how much you understand, and I'm so impressed with how you figured that out. Now, you said Midas was sad and hungry. Let’s zoom out a little bit. Why did he make that wish in the first place? What did he *think* was going to happen when he wished for the golden touch? Do you remember what he wanted? Take your time, you're doing wonderfully!: Teacher

(Takes a deep breath, trying to remember) Okay, okay... (Paces back and forth a little) He wished for the golden touch because... because he liked gold! (Stops pacing and looks at the teacher) He thought it would be… FUN! (Tilts head) He probably thought he would be super rich and happy! Like, he could have a golden car and a golden house and… and everything would be shiny and sparkly! (Claps hands together) He wanted ALL the gold! (Frowns suddenly) But... (Stuttering a little) I think he forgot that… that gold isn't everything. (Looks down, shuffling feet) He forgot about… about the important stuff, like… like hugs and grapes. (Looks up, eyes wide) He thought gold would make him happy, but it didn't! (Voice trembling slightly): Student

You've been doing such a fantastic job piecing everything together! You've shown me you really understand Midas's feelings, his wish, and why things went wrong. Now, in your own words, can you tell me the whole story of Midas, from the beginning to the end, focusing on why he wasn't happy even with all that gold?: Teacher

(Takes a big breath, trying to organize thoughts) Okay, so… (Starts to explain with hand gestures) King Midas was nice to a Satyr, and then Dionysus, the wine god, said he could have a wish! (Eyes light up) And Midas, he really liked gold! He thought gold was the BEST thing ever! (Frowns) So, he wished that everything he touched would turn to gold! (Shakes head) Dionysus warned him not to, but Midas didn't listen! (Voice gets a little sad) Then, everything started turning to gold! He was so excited at first! But then he got hungry! And he couldn't eat because his food turned to gold! It wasn't yummy anymore, just hard and… and metal-y! (Looks down) And then… (Voice cracks a little) his daughter hugged him, and she turned to gold too! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes filled with tears) (Wipes eyes with the back of hand) And then Midas was REALLY sad! He realized that gold wasn't everything! He couldn't eat, and he couldn't hug his daughter! (Voice is stronger now) He learned that being rich isn't as important as… as having people you love and being able to eat yummy food! (Looks at teacher, determined) He wasn't happy because he only thought about gold, and he forgot about the things that REALLY matter! That's why he wasn't happy, even with ALL that gold! (Nods firmly, feeling proud of explaining the whole story): Student

That's absolutely brilliant! You've explained the whole story so clearly, and you really understand why Midas wasn't happy. You should be incredibly proud of yourself! I've really enjoyed working with you today. Goodbye for now, and keep up the amazing work!: Teacher

rightDialog.content:
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's a bit of a sad story, isn't it? What part of the story made you feel the saddest?: Teacher

(Fidgets with my hands, looks down at my shoes) Uh... (long pause)... when... uh... (stuttering) ...when the... uh... the girl... turned gold. (Looks away, nervously): Student

That *is* a sad part. It's okay to feel that way. Can you tell me one thing you noticed about *how* the story describes her turning to gold?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, bites lip) ...Uh... It... it said she... hugged him? (Peeks up at the teacher quickly, then looks back down): Student

That's right, she hugged him. You're doing great! Now, what do you think that hug tells us about how she felt about her father?: Teacher

(Shrugs, voice barely a whisper) ...Uh... Liked him? (Looks at the floor, kicking a small stone) ...A lot?: Student

Yes, she liked him a lot! You're really understanding this. It can be a bit upsetting to think about, so we can take a break if you like. But if you're okay to keep going, let's think about *why* the story tells us she hugged him *right* before she turned to gold. What does that timing tell us?: Teacher

(Eyes widen a little, face scrunches up in concentration. Fidgets again.) ...Uh... (long pause)... Because... (stuttering) ...he was sad? (Looks up at the teacher with a worried expression) ...She wanted to make him... happy?: Student

You've picked up on so much already, even the tricky parts! To make sure we've got everything clear, could you try to tell me everything you've worked out about the story so far, in your own words? Don't worry if it's not perfect, just try your best.: Teacher

(Looks down at my hands, takes a deep breath, trembling slightly.) ...Uh... (very quiet voice)... King Midas... he helped someone... and got a wish... and wished for gold... (pauses, close to tears)... Then... everything turned gold... even food... (sniffs)... and his daughter... she hugged him... 'cause he was sad... and she turned gold too... (voice cracks) ...because... (long pause, struggling) ...the gold... was bad? (Looks up, eyes wide and pleading): Student

That's a really good summary, and it's okay to feel sad about it. You're absolutely right, the gold *was* bad, even though Midas thought it would be good at first. You've understood the story really well. Well done for working through it, even when it was upsetting! We're all done for today now, so have a good rest of your day and I'll see you next time.: Teacher

leftDialog.content:
Okay, great job reading the story! First, can you tell me, who was King Midas?: Teacher

(Looks down, fidgeting with my pencil) Uh... (pause) ... King... Midas... was a... (stuttering) ... a king. (Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down): Student

That's right! He *was* a king. Good job! Now, what did King Midas do that made Dionysus want to give him a wish?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) ... Uh... he... he helped... someone? (Looks at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes) ... I... I don't remember the name... (voice trails off): Student

You're right! He helped someone. The story said it was a Satyr. That's a tricky word! So, because he helped the Satyr, Dionysus gave him a wish. What did Midas wish for?: Teacher

(Looks down at my hands, twisting them) ... (long pause) ... Gold. He wished for... gold... (whispers) everything to be gold... (eyes welling up slightly): Student

Yes! He wished for everything he touched to turn to gold. Did Dionysus think it was a good wish?: Teacher

(Shakes head slowly, eyes wide and a little teary) ... Uh-uh... He... he said no... (sniffles quietly) ... but... Midas... wanted it anyway...: Student

That's right. Dionysus warned him. Now, after he got his wish, was Midas happy at first? What did he do?: Teacher

(Wipes eyes with the back of my hand) ... He... he touched stuff. (pause) ... Made it gold. (looks up at the teacher, then quickly down again) ... He... he was happy... at first... (voice shaky): Student

Yes, he was happy at first! He touched lots of things and turned them to gold. But what happened later? What went wrong? Think about lunchtime.: Teacher

(Frowns, thinking hard) ... Lunch... (voice barely audible) ... He couldn't... eat? (Looks up at the teacher, a flicker of hope in my eyes) ... 'Cause it turned to gold? (Quickly looks down again, nervous): Student

Yes! He couldn't eat! The food turned to gold. And then, what happened with his daughter?: Teacher

(Eyes widen, face crumples a little, voice trembling) ... His... his daughter... (swallows hard) ... she... she hugged him... and... and she turned... gold too? (Looks up at the teacher with a pleading look) ... Oh no... (whispers): Student

Yes. She turned to gold too. So, was the golden touch a good thing for Midas?: Teacher

(Shakes head vigorously, tears streaming down face now) ... No! (Voice cracks) ... It was bad! (Hides face in hands, sobbing quietly) ... He couldn't eat... and his daughter...: Student

You're right, it was very bad. He couldn't eat, and he turned his daughter into gold. Why do you think it turned out to be so bad? What did Midas want so much?: Teacher

(Sniffling, peeking between fingers) ... He wanted... gold. (Quietly) ... He wanted lots and lots of gold... (Looks at the teacher, then down again) ... But... but he couldn't... he couldn't eat... or hug his daughter... (voice trails off): Student

He wanted lots and lots of gold. And that's what made him forget about other important things, like eating and hugging his daughter. So, what do you think we can learn from this story? What's the big idea of the story?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, tapping foot nervously) ... (long pause) ... Maybe... maybe gold isn't... the most important thing? (Looks up at the teacher hesitantly) ... Maybe... maybe love... and food... are more important? (Voice barely audible) I... I don't know... (Looks down again, fiddling with pencil): Student

You're getting very close! You're right, love and food *are* more important. Midas wanted *more* and *more* gold, even when he had enough. What do you call someone who always wants more and more? Is that a good thing?: Teacher

(Thinking, then a small frown appears) ... Greedy? (Looks up at the teacher, unsure) ... Is that... the word? (Worried expression) ... Greedy is... bad? (Voice questioning): Student

Yes! Greedy! That's the word. And you're right, being greedy is often not a good thing. So, what happens to Midas because he was so greedy?: Teacher

(Eyes downcast, voice small) ... He... he lost... his daughter... and he was hungry... (sniffles) ... because he was greedy... (Looks up at the teacher, a tiny bit of understanding in eyes) ... So... being greedy... is bad... because you can lose... important things?: Student

Exactly! Because he was so greedy, he lost the things that were truly important: his daughter and even his ability to eat. So the story is trying to tell us that being too greedy can lead to bad things happening. It can lead to your downfall. You understood that very well. : Teacher

rightDialog.content:
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's a really interesting one. What part of the story stood out to you the most?: Teacher

(Eyes wide, a little fidgety) Oh! (Looks at the book on the desk) Um… the… the gold! (Points at an imaginary gold object) Everything turning to gold was… was so cool! (Voice gets a bit shaky) But… but also… scary. Like, really, really scary. I liked when he touched the… (Sticks out tongue slightly, concentrating) … the… uh… things! And they went *poof* gold! (Makes a small exploding gesture with hands, then quickly pulls them back). But… (Looks down at my hands) But then his… his (voice cracks slightly) daughter… turned to gold too. (Looks up, face crumpling a little) That was… that was the part that stood out. Was that… a bad wish? I… I thought gold was good.: Student

It's completely understandable that you felt scared! It *is* scary when something that seems good, like gold, suddenly becomes a problem. And it's especially sad about his daughter. You're right, gold *can* be good, but let's think about *why* it wasn't good for Midas. He was so excited when things turned to gold at first. Why do you think he wanted everything to be gold so badly? What do you think he was hoping to get from it?: Teacher

(Fidgets with my hands again, looking down, then back up quickly) Uh… because… (Thinking hard, brow furrowed) because gold is… is shiny! (Confidently) And… and it's worth a lot! Like, you can buy candy with it! (Eyes widen) And toys! Lots and lots of toys! (Starts to get excited) He… he probably thought he could get anything he wanted! (Starts to bounce slightly in my seat) He could have a GIANT candy store! Made of gold! (Suddenly stops bouncing, face falling slightly) But… but he couldn’t eat the candy, could he? (Looks down again, voice small) Everything he touched went *poof* gold. Even the yummy things. (Looks up, a little confused) Was he… greedy? Is that why?: Student

You're doing a great job thinking about this, and it's okay to feel a little confused – it's a confusing story! You're absolutely right, he couldn't eat the candy, could he? And you're getting close to understanding why. He *was* excited about the shiny gold and all the things he could buy. That excitement, that wanting *more* and *more*, is something we call greed. Don't worry it is a tricky word. You noticed that his daughter turned to gold, and that made you feel sad, right? So, if Midas wasn’t able to hug his daughter, or eat food, was the gold still making him happy? Or was it doing the opposite?: Teacher

(Sniffles slightly, wiping nose with back of hand) No! (Shakes head vigorously) It wasn't making him happy! He… he looked really sad. (Voice wavers) And scared! Because… (Thinking hard, chewing on lip) because he couldn't… he couldn't hug his daughter anymore. (Tears well up a little) (Looks up, voice trembling) So… so even though he had lots and lots of gold… (Swallows hard) …he didn't have… happy things. (Looks down, whispering) He didn't have his daughter. (Looks back up, eyes pleading) Was it because he was too… too greedy?: Student

You're so close to understanding, and it's okay to feel sad about it. It *is* a sad story! You're right, even with all that gold, he didn't have the things that *really* mattered, like being able to hug his daughter. Think about it like this: he wanted all that gold so he could have anything he wanted, right? But what happened when he *actually* got it? Did he really get everything he wanted, or did he *lose* something important?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, forehead wrinkled) He… he lost his daughter! (Voice stronger now, understanding dawning) And he couldn't eat! So… so he *thought* he wanted the gold… but he really wanted… (Looks around the room, searching for the right words) …he really wanted the *other* things. The things gold can't buy. (Looks at you, eyes wide) Like hugs! And… and food! And… and maybe… maybe just being with people he loved?: Student

You've really thought deeply about this story, and you've understood so much! Can you put all those thoughts together and tell me in your own words what this story is *really* about? What did Midas learn, and what does the story teach *us*?: Teacher

(Takes a deep breath, trying to stay calm) Okay. (Looks at the book, then back at you) The story… the story is about… about how… (Stutters a little) …how wanting too much stuff… even gold… isn't always good. (Voice gets stronger) It's about how… (Looks down at hands, then back up) …how things that seem good… like shiny gold… can actually make you sad if you don't have… (Searching for the right word again) … the *important* things. (Stands up straighter, more confident) Midas learned that… that hugs and food and… and being with his daughter… (Smiles faintly) …are more important than gold. (Looks directly at you) And the story teaches *us* that… that we should be happy with what we have… and not be too… (Pauses, struggling with the word) …greedy! Because… because the important things aren't things you can buy with gold. (Sits back down, feeling relieved): Student

That's absolutely brilliant! You've understood the story perfectly. You explained it so well, and you're right, the important things in life *aren't* things you can buy. I'm really proud of how much you've learned today. Have a wonderful day!: Teacher

leftDialog.content:
Okay, great job reading the story of King Midas! That was a bit of a sad story, wasn't it? Let's see if we can remember what happened. Who was King Midas? What did he do?: Teacher

(Eyes wide, a little fidgety) Um... King Midas? (Looks down at my hands) He... he was a king! (Confident now, remembering the story) And he helped a... a Satyr! (Smiles proudly) He was nice to him! And then... and then the god... the wine god... (Sticks tongue out, concentrating) Dionysus! He said King Midas could have a wish!: Student

Excellent! You remembered all of that! Dionysus did offer him a wish. What did King Midas wish for?: Teacher

(Bounces a little in my seat, excited) He wished... he wished for everything he touched... (Looks up, remembering carefully) ...to turn to GOLD! (Claps hands together excitedly, then immediately shrinks back, nervous) He... he really wanted that! (Frowns a little, remembering the sad part): Student

Yes, he did! He wanted everything he touched to turn to gold. Now, after he got his wish, was King Midas happy at first? What did he do?: Teacher

(Nods head enthusiastically, then wrings hands together) Yes! Yes! He was SO happy! (Voice gets louder, more excited) He touched his chair and it turned to gold! And then... then he touched a table! GOLD! (Looks at the teacher with wide eyes, then lowers voice) He... he was really, really happy... at first. (Worried look on face): Student

You're right! He was very happy at first. But what happened after a while? Did he *stay* happy?: Teacher

(Looks down at shoes, shuffling them) No... (Voice is very quiet) He got hungry. (Looks up quickly, then down again) But... but when he tried to eat... his food turned into gold too! (Starts to tear up a little) And... and then his daughter... (Sniffs, voice trembling) she wanted to hug him... and... (Voice cracks) she turned into gold too! (Looks up at the teacher, eyes pleading) It was... it was terrible!: Student

It *was* terrible! You're absolutely right. So, King Midas got his wish, but in the end, was it a good wish?: Teacher

(Shakes head emphatically, tears welling up) No! (Wipes eyes with back of hand) It was the worst wish EVER! (Sticks out lower lip and frowns) He couldn't eat! And... and he turned his daughter into gold! (Looks at the teacher, anxiously) He didn't want that! He didn't!: Student

He certainly didn't want that. So, he thought having everything turn to gold would make him happy, but it didn't. Why do you think it didn't make him happy? What went wrong?: Teacher

(Bites lip, thinking hard. Stares intently at the teacher) (Stuttering) Um... because... because he couldn't... he couldn't eat the gold! (Points to stomach) And he couldn't... he couldn't hug his daughter! (Frowns, confused) Gold is... is pretty. But... but you can't... you can't eat it. And you can't... (Voice trails off, uncertain) Can I ask a question?: Student

Of course, you can ask a question! What is it?: Teacher

(Looks at the teacher with big, hopeful eyes) Did... did the wine god... Dionysus... did he change her back? Did he make his daughter not gold anymore? (Voice full of hope) I really hope so!: Student

That's a very good question. The story doesn't *exactly* say, but it does say that King Midas learned a lesson and begged Dionysus to take the golden touch away. And Dionysus, being a kind god, told him how to wash the gold away. So, what do you think? If King Midas could wash the gold away from everything else, do you think he could wash it away from his daughter too?: Teacher

(Eyes widen, hope flooding back into face. Claps hands softly) Oh! Oh, I hope so! (Nods head vigorously) If he washed it all away, then she would be okay! (Voice is lighter, happier) And then he could eat again too! (Smiles shyly) That's good! That's really good! (Relief washes over face): Student

It *is* good! So, King Midas learned that even though gold is pretty, it isn't the most important thing, right? What are some things that are *more* important than gold, do you think?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, tapping a finger on the desk) (Looks at the teacher hesitantly) Um... food? (Looks down, then back up, gaining confidence) And... and hugs! (Smiles brightly) And... (Scrunches up face, concentrating) ... and being able to... to play outside! (Nods head decisively) Yes! Those are more important! Way more important than just gold!: Student

You got it! Food, hugs, playing outside... those are all wonderful things that are much more important than gold. So, if King Midas was so unhappy even though he had so much gold, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea, the lesson, of the story? Why do you think the author wrote it?: Teacher

(Looks away, a little nervous, then looks back at the teacher) (Quietly) Um... (Bites lip again) Maybe... maybe it's trying to say that... that just because you *want* something really, really bad... it doesn't mean it will make you happy? (Voice gets a little stronger) And... and that sometimes... the things you already *have*... like food and hugs... (Smiles) ... are the best things ever? (Looks at the teacher, a little anxiously) Is that right?: Student

That's *absolutely* right! You figured it out! Sometimes wanting too much, or being too greedy, can actually make us unhappy. King Midas was so greedy for gold, he forgot about the things that really mattered. So, we could say that being too greedy, wanting too much, can lead to your own downfall. It can make you lose the things that are truly important. Does that make sense?: Teacher

(Nods head enthusiastically, relieved and proud) Yes! It makes lots of sense! (Voice is confident and happy) So... so it's better to be happy with what you have! (Thinks for a moment) And... and to be nice to people, like King Midas was nice to the Satyr! (Smiles at the teacher) I understand! (Claps hands once, softly): Student

You really do understand! You did a fantastic job thinking about the story and figuring out what it means. I'm very proud of you! : Teacher

Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's quite a fascinating tale, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most?: Teacher

(Looks down, fidgeting with my pencil) Uh... (long pause) the gold part.: Student

Yes, the gold is a key part! It's pretty amazing, isn't it, this idea of turning things to gold? Can you tell me one thing about the gold that you found interesting? It doesn't have to be a big thing, just anything that popped into your head.: Teacher

(Thinking, chews on my pencil eraser) ...That... that the food turned to gold? (Looks up quickly, then down again): Student

That's a great observation! The food turning to gold *is* a pretty important detail. It shows us that Midas' wish wasn't as wonderful as he thought it would be, doesn't it? What do you think might have been going through his head when he realised he couldn't eat?: Teacher

(Looks away, shrugs) ...Uh... sad? (Quietly) Because... no food?: Student

You got it exactly right! Sad is definitely a big part of it. And you're spot on – because there was no food! You're really understanding this. Now, thinking about *why* he's sad... can you think of another word, maybe something a bit stronger than "sad," to describe how Midas might have felt when his food turned to gold? It's okay if you're not sure, just take a guess!: Teacher

(Thinking hard, wrinkles forehead) ...Uh... (hesitates) ...frus...frustrated? 'Cause he wanted to eat, but he... couldn't? (Looks up, hopeful): Student

Frustrated is a *fantastic* word! It fits perfectly. You're doing so well at understanding how Midas felt! Now, just to make sure we've got it all clear, can you tell me in your own words what we've talked about so far regarding the story, focusing on how Midas felt about the golden touch?: Teacher

(Looks down at my hands, tracing the lines on my palm. Mumbles) ...He wanted gold... everything gold... (pause) ...Then... food gold... (longer pause) ...he's... frustrated. (Looks up, a little confused) Is 'frustrated' like... really, really sad?: Student

Yes, "frustrated" can be like "really, really sad," especially when you're trying to do something important, like eat, and you just... can't! You've got the main idea of the story, and you explained it so well! Well done! I think you have a great understanding of the story. Have a great day!: Teacher

rightDialog.content:
Okay, great job reading the story! That was "The Golden Touch." First, can you tell me, who was King Midas?: Teacher

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting a bit) Uh… (pauses) … King… Midas… was a… king? (Looks up quickly, then down again) He… he lived in… Greece?: Student

Yes! You got it. He was a king who lived in Greece. Now, what did King Midas do that made the god Dionysus happy?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, scrunching up my nose) He… he helped… uh… (looks up at the teacher, eyes wide) … a Satyr? (Looks down again, tracing a pattern on the desk with my finger) He was… nice to him?: Student

Exactly! He helped a Satyr. And because he was so kind, Dionysus offered him a wish. What did King Midas wish for?: Teacher

(Eyes light up a little, but still hesitant) He… (pauses, thinking)... he wished for… everything he touched… (looks at the teacher, then back down)… to turn to… gold? (Says it like a question, unsure) Everything!: Student

Yes! That's right. He wished everything he touched would turn to gold. How did he feel when Dionysus gave him the golden touch? Was he happy or sad?: Teacher

(Confidently) Happy! (Smiling slightly) Very happy! (Pauses) He thought it was… awesome! He touched… (starts to look around the room, then stops himself) … lots of stuff! (Looks down again, a small frown forming): Student

He was very happy at first. What sorts of things did he turn to gold?: Teacher

(Thinking, tapping a finger on the desk) Um… (pauses) Food? (Looks up, questioning) And… and stuff in his… palace? Like… chairs? (Frowns a little): Student

Yes, food and chairs! Good job. But what happened when he tried to eat the food? What was the problem?: Teacher

(Eyes widen a bit, remembering) Uh… (hesitates) … it turned to… gold? (Looks at the teacher, worried) He couldn’t… eat it? (Stomach rumbles): Student

That's right! He couldn't eat it. Gold isn't very tasty, is it? So, he couldn't eat. Was there anything else that went wrong with his wish?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, chewing on the inside of my cheek) …His… daughter? (Looks up at the teacher, voice small) She… she hugged him? And… and she turned into… gold too? (Looks down at my lap, fiddling with my hands) Is that… is that right?: Student

Yes, that's exactly right. His daughter hugged him and she turned to gold. How do you think King Midas felt when that happened? Was he still happy about his golden touch?: Teacher

(Shakes head slowly, looking down) …No… (voice barely a whisper). He was… sad? (Looks up, a little confused) Really, really sad. He didn’t want her to… to be gold. (Frowns) He didn’t want the gold anymore.: Student

That's right. He was very sad. He realised the golden touch wasn't such a good thing after all. Why do you think he wished for the golden touch in the first place? What did he want?: Teacher

(Thinking, tilting my head) He… (pauses) … he wanted to be… rich? (Looks up, unsure) He liked gold? Shiny things? (Looks down again) He… he didn’t think about… about the other stuff. (Frowns deeply): Student

He did want to be rich. He really, really liked gold. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? What's the big idea we should remember from "The Golden Touch?" Think about what King Midas wanted and what happened to him in the end.: Teacher

(Thinking really hard, almost closing my eyes) …That… (long pause)… that wanting too much… (opens eyes, looks up at the teacher) …isn’t always… good? (Looks down again, tracing patterns on the desk) That… that some things are more important than… gold? Like… (hesitates) …like people? (Voice is very soft): Student

Yes! You're getting it! Wanting too much isn't always good. And some things, like people, are much more important than gold. So, if someone is always wanting more and more, even when they have enough, what might happen to them?: Teacher

(Looks up, thinking) …They might… (pauses) …forget about… the things they already have? (Looks down again, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) And… and make people… sad? (Voice is quiet): Student

Yes, they might forget about the things they already have and maybe even make people sad. King Midas loved gold so much, he forgot what was really important. So, the story teaches us to be careful about being too greedy. If you are too greedy, it can lead to bad things happening. Does that make sense?: Teacher

(Nods slowly, looking at the teacher) …Yeah… (pauses) …It makes sense. (A small smile appears) So… so it’s better to be… thankful for what I have? (Looks down, then back up at the teacher, a little brighter) Even if it’s not… gold?: Student

Exactly! It's much better to be thankful for what you have. Even if it's not gold. You understood the story really well and you figured out the lesson all by yourself! : Teacher

Okay, great job reading the story! That was a long one. First, tell me: Who was King Midas?: Teacher

(Beaming and raising my hand eagerly) I know, I know! King Midas was... (pauses, tapping my chin thoughtfully, but answers confidently) a Greek king! And he did something nice for a Satyr!: Student

That's right! He was a Greek king. And you remembered about the Satyr! Because he was nice, what did Dionysus offer him?: Teacher

(Eyes wide, I bounce slightly in my seat) Dionysus... Dionysus was the god of wine! (Speaking clearly and excitedly) And he gave King Midas a... a... (Sticks tongue out, concentrating) a... wish! (Looks up, proud) He gave him a wish because he was nice!: Student

Excellent! He did indeed. What did King Midas wish for?: Teacher

(Eyes sparkling, hands clasped in front of me) He wished that... everything he touched would turn to... gold! (Nodding enthusiastically) All shiny and gold! (Confidently) He really, really wanted that!: Student

He sure did! Now, after he got his wish, what happened when he tried to eat?: Teacher

(Frowning slightly, but still eager to answer) Oh! Oh, that was bad! (Thinking) He... he couldn't eat! (A little louder) Because the food... (pauses, choosing my words carefully) the food turned into gold too! He couldn't eat yummy bread or anything! (Shakes head, looking a bit sad).: Student

That's right! He couldn't eat anything. And then, what happened with his daughter?: Teacher

(My face falls, and I look down at my hands for a moment) Oh no... (Looks back up, eyes wide with slight worry) His daughter... she wanted to hug him, because he was sad! (Voice gets a little quieter) But when she hugged him... she turned into gold too! (Shakes my head sadly) It's not a good wish!: Student

No, it wasn't a good wish. Now, after all of that happened, how did King Midas feel about his golden touch? Did he still think it was a good thing?: Teacher

(Shaking my head vigorously) No! No, he didn't! (Confidently) He learned it wasn't a good wish at all! (Thinking) He was probably very sad! (Looks at you expectantly) Because he couldn't eat and his daughter was gold!: Student

You're exactly right! He was very sad. So, what do you think this story is trying to teach us? Why wasn't the golden touch a good thing, even though gold seems wonderful?: Teacher

(Tilts head, thinking hard) Hmmm... (Sticks tongue out a little) It... it teaches us that... (Choosing my words carefully) that... things aren't always good just because they're shiny! (Looks up, confident again) He thought gold was the best, but he needed... (pauses) food! And hugs! (Nods emphatically) So, it's better to have food and hugs than just gold!: Student

That's a very good way to put it! So, what if King Midas wasn't so eager to have *everything* turn to gold? What if he was happy with what he already had?: Teacher

(Eyes widen, considering the question) Hmmm... (Thinking, tapping my finger on the table) If he was happy already... then he wouldn't need the wish! (Excitedly) He could still eat his food, and he could still hug his daughter! (Smiling brightly) So, it's good to be happy with what you have! (Nods enthusiastically).: Student

Yes! It's good to be happy with what you have. Wanting too much, or always wanting *more*, can lead to bad things. Does that give you an idea of what the story is trying to teach us?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) So... (Voice a little lower, concentrating) wanting too much... is bad... (Looks up, eyes sparkling with understanding) It's like... being greedy! The story teaches us not to be greedy! (Nods, very pleased with myself) Because then you might turn your daughter into gold! (Giggles a little at the thought, then becomes serious again): Student

You got it! Being greedy, wanting too much, can lead to bad things happening. The story teaches us that being happy with what you have is much better than always wanting more. You understood the story really well. : Teacher

leftDialog.content:
Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's a pretty interesting one, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most?: Teacher

(Eyes wide, bouncing a little on my heels) Oh! Oh! I liked when King Midas touched things and they turned to GOLD! (claps hands excitedly) It was like *magic*! Everything went *shining*! I think that part was the bestest! He touched the chair and it was gold! He touched the table and it was gold! (pauses, thinking) Was it *really* gold, or just *looked* like gold?: Student

Ooooh! So *shiny*! Let's imagine we're inspecting his golden chair! What does it *feel* like to sit on? Is it comfy, or hard and cold like a *real* gold statue?: Teacher

(Jumps up and pretends to sit on an invisible chair, then wrinkles nose) Hmmm... (touches my cheek thoughtfully) I think...I think it would be *hard*! (confidently) Because gold is hard! Like my momma's ring! It's not *soft* like my teddy bear! (shivers dramatically) And it would be *cold*! Like...like an ice cube! (excitedly) So it wouldn't be comfy at *all*! It would be a *shiny*, *hard*, *cold* chair!: Student

(Eyes widen, hands clasped dramatically to chest) Oh my stars! A *golden* chair! Imagine the *glitter*! But you're right! (Taps chin thoughtfully) It wouldn't be very cuddly, would it? What if King Midas tried to eat a golden... (pauses for dramatic effect) ...*pizza*! What do you think THAT would be like? Take a biiig bite! (Pretends to bite into a pizza with exaggerated chewing motions): Teacher

(Giggles and then makes a face) Ewww! (shudders) A golden pizza! (thinking hard) Okay, so... the crust would be hard and shiny, like the chair, right? And the cheese... (eyes widen in horror) ...the cheese would be *gold* too! And the pepperoni! (Sticks tongue out) It would be like... like biting a rock! (Makes a gagging sound) It wouldn't taste good at all! It would taste like... *metal*! Yuck! No pizza for King Midas! (shakes head emphatically) Pizza has to be soft and cheesy, not hard and gold!: Student

(Gasps dramatically, clutching stomach) Oh dear, oh dear! No pizza! What's a king to do? (Looks around dramatically, then points a finger at the student with mock seriousness) But wait! He has a *daughter*! A lovely, huggable daughter! What happens when he gives her a biiiiig, loving *hug*? (Opens arms wide for an imaginary hug, beaming expectantly) Do you think that turns out okay?: Teacher

(Eyes widen and the smile fades a little) Oh... oh no... (Looks down at my hands, fidgeting) He... he hugs her... and she turns to gold too... (Voice gets quieter) She can't... she can't hug him back then, can she? (Looks up, a little worried) That's... that's not good. That's... that's *sad*. (Frowns) Why would he hug her if he knew she would turn to gold? (Looks at the teacher expectantly): Student

You've thought so much about the chair, the pizza, and... oh dear, his daughter! (Sighs dramatically, then smiles encouragingly). You've really understood what happened in the story! Now, in your own words, can you tell me everything that happened to King Midas from the very beginning after he got his wish? Just tell me the main things that happened.: Teacher

(Takes a deep breath, trying to remember everything) Okay! Okay! So... (counts on fingers) First, King Midas got a wish because he was nice to a satyr. Then he wished that everything he touched would turn to gold! (Eyes light up with excitement again) Then... then he started touching everything! The chair! The table! (Pause, frowns slightly) Then he got hungry, but he couldn't eat anything because it turned to gold. And... and then his daughter came to hug him, but she turned to gold too! (Voice gets quiet and sad) And then... and then he was sad because he couldn't eat and his daughter was gold. (Looks at the teacher, a little uncertain) Did I get it all?: Student

That's absolutely perfect! You remembered every important part, and you explained it so clearly. You really understood the story of King Midas and his golden touch. I'm so proud of how well you listened and thought about everything! Now, it's time for you to go, but I'll see you next time! Bye!: Teacher

Okay, [User's Name], you just finished reading "The Golden Touch"! That was a pretty interesting story, wasn't it? Tell me, who was the main character in the story?: Teacher

(Eyes widen, fidgeting with my hands) Oh! Oh! I know! (Running ahead) It was King...King... (Stuttering) Ki-King...Midas! (Confidently) Yeah! King Midas! He...he was the king in the story! (Looks away, nervous) He was a...a...nice king, I think? (Asks question to the teacher) Was he a nice king? Because he did a good deed...right?: Student

That's right! The main character was King Midas! Good job remembering his name! You're also right that he did a good deed. What good deed did he do?: Teacher

(Jumping in excitement) Oh! Oh! (Uses significantly longer utterances) He helped a...a Satyr! (Thinking, scratching my head) A Satyr is like a...a man with goat legs, right? (Asks questions to the teacher) Is that right? (Looks away, anxious) I get kinda nervous when I need to...re...re... (Stuttering) re-member things. (Being polite and kind) But I'm trying my best! He was nice to the Satyr and that's why he got a wish! (Thinks beyond the given information) I wonder if the Satyr was lost. Maybe King Midas helped him find his way home!: Student

You are doing a fantastic job! Yes, a Satyr is like a man with goat legs. And you're right, King Midas helped the Satyr. Because he was so kind, he got a wish! What did King Midas wish for?: Teacher

(Eyes light up, excited) Oh! This is the best part! (Uses complex words) He wished for...for the *extraordinary* ability for everything he touched to turn into... (dramatic shift in mood - looks down, anxious) ...gold. (Nervous in the conversation) I get a funny feeling in my tummy thinking about it. (Asks questions to the teacher, tugging on sleeve) Was it a good wish? Dionysus...he said it wasn't a good wish, right? (Thinks beyond the given information) I wonder why Midas wanted everything to be gold? Did he want to be super rich?: Student

You remembered that perfectly! King Midas wished that everything he touched would turn to gold. And you're right, Dionysus warned him. Why do you think Dionysus warned him that it might not be a good wish? What happened after he got the golden touch?: Teacher

(Confidently, even though a little scared) I know! I know why it wasn't a good wish! (Eyes widen, voice gets high-pitched) Because he couldn't eat! (Dramatic shift in mood, looking sad) And he turned his daughter into gold! (Uses significantly longer utterances, getting emotional) He touched his food and it turned to gold, so he was hungry! And his daughter... (Stuttering) h-h-his daughter just wanted to give him a hug because he looked sad, and then *poof*! She was a golden statue! (Thinks beyond the given information, asking questions) But...but if he touched her again *after* he lost the golden touch, would she be okay again? (Anxious, fidgeting) I hope so! That's so scary! (Looks away, starting to tear up a little): Student

You're exactly right! He couldn't eat, and he turned his daughter into gold. It *is* a very sad part of the story. So, after all that happened, did King Midas still think the golden touch was a good thing?: Teacher

(Shakes head vigorously, voice trembling) No! (Uses complex words) Absolutely not! (Feeling anxious, wrapping arms around self) He realised it was a *terrible* wish! (Thinks beyond the given information, asks questions) I wonder how he got rid of it? Did he have to go back to Dionysus and say he was sorry? (Looks away, feeling overwhelmed) That would be hard. (Being polite and kind, even though upset) Thank you for asking me about the story. (Dramatic shift in mood, almost crying) It's just... it's so sad about his daughter!: Student

You're doing great! You understand the story so well. Yes, he learned it was a terrible wish. He did go back and ask Dionysus to take the wish away, and Dionysus told him how to get rid of it. So, what do you think we can learn from the story of King Midas? What's the big idea or lesson that the story is trying to teach us?: Teacher

(Thinking hard, tapping chin) Hmmm... (Looks away, easily distracted) Is it almost time for recess? (Immediately focuses back, feeling guilty) Oh! But the lesson... (Uses significantly longer utterances, trying to explain) I think it means that... that just because something *looks* really, really good, doesn't mean it *is* really, really good. (Thinks beyond the given information, using complex words) Like... like sometimes things that seem *superficial* aren't really important. (Nervous in the conversation, fiddling with clothes) Is that right? (Asks question to the teacher) Is that what it means?
